G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, and Defendant transacts business and operates its facility there.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or operator that invites children onto its premises for a supervised program owes those children a duty to exercise reasonable care in the operation and supervision of activities on the premises. See, e.g., Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (establishing general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors); Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747–48 (1988) (landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining premises).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful visitors. That principle logically encompasses children invited onto premises for supervised programs, but the case does not specifically discuss children or structured programs; it supplies only the broad doctrinal foundation that a landowner must act as a reasonable person toward lawful entrants. Thus it supports the general duty statement, though only by implication for the specific context described.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore hold that the duty of care owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is the duty to act as a reasonable man in all the circumstances." 363 Mass. at 707–08 (paraphrased from the main opinion; Kaplan, J., concurring, criticizing continued special treatment of trespassers and supporting the move away from rigid entrant classifications).

Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or operator that invites children onto its premises for a supervised program owes those children a duty to exercise reasonable care in the operation and supervision of activities on the premises. See, e.g., Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973) (establishing general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors); Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747–48 (1988) (landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining premises).
Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747\u.support_reasoning: The case does restate the general Massachusetts rule that a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, citing Mounsey. However, it does not address or establish any special duty arising from the fact that children are invited onto the premises for a supervised program, nor does it discuss operation and supervision of activities as a distinct duty. The opinion actually finds no liability for the landowner (YWCA) beyond the standard premises-liability duty, so it does not support the more specific proposition asserted.
Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747\u.relevant_excerpt: “A property owner has a duty to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition. Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). Thorson makes no claim before us, however, that the YWCA’s auditorium was not in reasonably safe condition. Nor does she claim that the YWCA did anything to cause her injury.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 54–57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: The standard of care applicable to Defendant includes the obligation to provide adequate supervision of children engaged in physical activities, to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm from rough or dangerous play, and to act as a reasonably prudent operator of a youth recreation program under like circumstances. See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 54–57 (1983) (duty to protect where harm is foreseeable and relationship gives rise to obligation to take reasonable precautions); Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246–47 (1982) (duty where harm to child is foreseeable).
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent focused solely on causation and foreseeability in the context of campus security and rape, not on the standard of care for supervising children in physical activities or youth recreation programs. While it discusses foreseeability and duty in premises/security terms, it does not articulate or apply any special duty of supervision over children engaged in rough or dangerous play. Thus, citing this case for a standard of care specific to youth recreation supervision overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982)... The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes."

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.proposition: The standard of care applicable to Defendant includes the obligation to provide adequate supervision of children engaged in physical activities, to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm from rough or dangerous play, and to act as a reasonably prudent operator of a youth recreation program under like circumstances. See Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 54–57 (1983) (duty to protect where harm is foreseeable and relationship gives rise to obligation to take reasonable precautions); Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246–47 (1982) (duty where harm to child is foreseeable).
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.support_reasoning: Schofield v. Merrill concerns the duty owed by landowners to an adult trespasser and expressly reaffirms that, absent willful, wanton, or reckless conduct (and narrow exceptions for imperiled or child trespassers), no duty of reasonable care is owed. It does not deal with supervision of children in physical activities, operation of youth recreation programs, or a general negligence standard based on foreseeability; rather, it limits duties to adult trespassers even when their presence is foreseeable. Citing Schofield for a broad foreseeability-based duty to supervise children in recreational settings mischaracterizes the case’s holding and context.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244, 246.relevant_excerpt: "We can say with confidence that landowners of ordinary prudence customarily exercise care for the safety of trespassers who are known to be in a position of peril, certain foreseeable child trespassers, and all lawful visitors. However, we are not convinced that landowners of ordinary prudence customarily exercise care for the safety of adult trespassers generally.... If the present case were to be tried... the jury would be warranted in finding that the plaintiff's intrusion was foreseeable by the defendants."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Under the established elements of negligence articulated in Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006), and Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281, Plaintiff must show: (a) a duty of reasonable care owed by Defendant to J.M.; (b) a breach of that duty; (c) a causal connection between the breach and the injury; and (d) actual damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The Jupin opinion expressly articulates the standard elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law, requiring proof of duty, breach, damages, and causal relation, and it cites a tort treatise in doing so. Those elements are substantively identical to the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 formulation referenced in the proposition. Thus, the case directly supports the statement that the plaintiff must show (a) duty, (b) breach, (c) causal connection, and (d) actual damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.” 447 Mass. at 146–47.

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454–55 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: The risk that unsupervised or inadequately supervised tackle‑style play between older and younger children on a hardwood gym floor would result in head injury or concussion to a smaller child, such as J.M., was reasonably foreseeable. See Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454–55 (1969) (foreseeability of harm central to duty and breach); Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007) (foreseeability guides scope of duty and breach analysis).
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: Carey concerns a bar’s duty to protect patrons from a violent, intoxicated customer and discusses foreseeability of violent acts in that specific context. It does not involve children, sports, play, supervision, head injuries, or gym environments, nor does it address the foreseeability of concussion-type harm from tackle-style play between older and younger children. While Carey affirms that foreseeability of harm is central to duty and breach generally, it does not provide authority for the specific foreseeability proposition stated about youth tackle play on a gym floor.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant… owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional… The jury in their judgment could find that the defendant’s agents should have realized that there was real danger to others. Nor was it fatal to the plaintiff’s case that the method of assault was not precisely foreseeable… Serving hard liquor, particularly to one already drunk… may well make the individual unreasonably aggressive… in which it is foreseeable that almost any irrational act is foreseeable.”

Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.raw_text: Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007)
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.proposition: The risk that unsupervised or inadequately supervised tackle‑style play between older and younger children on a hardwood gym floor would result in head injury or concussion to a smaller child, such as J.M., was reasonably foreseeable. See Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454–55 (1969) (foreseeability of harm central to duty and breach); Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 262–63 (2007) (foreseeability guides scope of duty and breach analysis).
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.support_reasoning: Afarian does not concern sports, children, or physical play; it is a roadway-utility‑pole wrongful death case. The cited pages are used for a general discussion of how reasonable foreseeability informs the existence and scope of duty in negligence, not for any proposition about foreseeability of head injuries from unsupervised tackle‑style play. Thus, Afarian can properly be cited only for the broad principle that foreseeability guides duty and breach analysis, not for the specific foreseeability conclusion stated in the proposition.
Afarian v. Massachusetts Elec. Co., 449.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … ‘[T]o the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty …, it is a test of the “reasonable foreseeability” of the harm.’”

Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.raw_text: Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987)
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of J.M.’s concussion and related injuries. But for Defendant’s breaches of its duty of care, including its failure to stop the tackle play upon being notified, J.M. would not have been tackled to the floor and would not have sustained a head injury. See Jupin, 447 Mass. at 146–47 (causation standard); Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987) (causation is satisfied where defendant’s conduct was a substantial contributing factor in producing harm).
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Solimene for the general causation standard that liability is satisfied where the defendant’s conduct is a substantial contributing factor in producing the harm. Solimene explicitly discusses proximate and intervening causation, including Restatement § 440’s definition that frames liability in terms of the defendant’s negligence being a substantial factor in bringing about the harm. While Solimene does not involve a concussion or failure to stop a tackle play, it is correctly cited as authority for the substantial-factor causation standard referenced in the proposition.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., 399 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: Restatement (Second) of Torts, supra at § 440, defines superseding cause as “an act of a third person or other force which by its intervention prevents the actor from being liable for harm to another which his antecedent negligence is a substantial factor in bringing about.” … The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.

Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109\u.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes the right of a minor child to recover for personal injuries caused by the negligence of another, including pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 6D (governing recovery for pain and suffering in negligence actions involving bodily injury); see also Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109–10 (1968) (adopting reasonable care standard in negligence actions); Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62, 71–72 (1993) (landowner and business operator’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect patrons from foreseeable harm).
Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109\u.support_reasoning: The opinion in Brune v. Belinkoff concerns the professional standard of care in medical malpractice actions (rejecting the locality rule and adopting an “average qualified practitioner”/reasonable care standard). It does not address the substantive rights of a minor child to recover for personal injuries, nor the availability of pain and suffering damages under Massachusetts negligence law. The case is therefore about the standard of care, not about who may recover or what categories of damages are recoverable, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109\u.relevant_excerpt: "We are of opinion that the 'locality' rule of Small v. Howard which measures a physician’s conduct by the standards of other doctors in similar communities is unsuited to present day conditions. The time has come when the medical profession should no longer be Balkanized by the application of varying geographic standards in malpractice cases. Accordingly, Small v. Howard is hereby overruled. The proper standard is whether the physician, if a general practitioner, has exercised the degree of care and skill of the average qualified practitioner, taking into account the advances in the profession."

Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes the right of a minor child to recover for personal injuries caused by the negligence of another, including pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 6D (governing recovery for pain and suffering in negligence actions involving bodily injury); see also Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109–10 (1968) (adopting reasonable care standard in negligence actions); Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62, 71–72 (1993) (landowner and business operator’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect patrons from foreseeable harm).
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.support_reasoning: Flood v. Southland Corp. concerns a landowner/business operator’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect patrons from foreseeable harm, including harm caused by third parties. It does not address, even indirectly, the distinct question of whether Massachusetts law recognizes a minor child’s right to recover for personal injuries (including pain and suffering) caused by negligence. While Flood is relevant to premises liability and foreseeability, it is not authority for the specific proposition about a minor’s right to recover for personal injuries and pain and suffering.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.relevant_excerpt: "Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 [1973]) to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional (Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452 [1969]). Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant."

Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153,.raw_text: Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153, 167–68 (1973)
Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a parent has an independent cause of action to recover medical expenses and other pecuniary losses incurred on behalf of an injured minor child as a result of a defendant’s negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85K (preserving negligence claims against certain charitable organizations subject to limitations); G.L. c. 233, § 20B (recognizing parent‑child relationship in context of medical testimony); see also Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153, 167–68 (1973) (recognizing independent claims related to injuries within the family context, by analogy).
Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153,.support_reasoning: Diaz concerns whether a spouse has an independent common‑law cause of action for loss of consortium arising from negligent injury to the other spouse. It does not address parents’ independent claims for medical expenses or other pecuniary losses incurred for an injured minor child, nor does it construe G.L. c. 231, § 85K or G.L. c. 233, § 20B. The brief discussion near the end about not necessarily extending consortium rights to other relationships (including parent‑child) actually cuts against using Diaz as analogical authority for such a parental cause of action.
Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153,.relevant_excerpt: “Nor does it follow that if the husband-wife relationship is protected as here envisaged, identical protection must be afforded by analogy to other relationships from that of parent-child in a lengthy regress to that of master-servant; courts will rather proceed from case to case with discerning caution.” (364 Mass. at 165)

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes the right of a minor child to recover for personal injuries caused by the negligence of another, including pain and suffering. See G.L. c. 231, § 6D (governing recovery for pain and suffering in negligence actions involving bodily injury); see also Brune v. Belinkoff, 354 Mass. 102, 109–10 (1968) (adopting reasonable care standard in negligence actions); Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62, 71–72 (1993) (landowner and business operator’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect patrons from foreseeable harm).

G.L. c. 230, \u00a7 5.proposition: Plaintiff brings this claim as parent and next friend of J.M. pursuant to applicable Massachusetts law permitting parents and guardians to sue on behalf of minors. See, e.g., G.L. c. 230, § 5 (actions by or on behalf of minors and persons under disability); Mass. R. Civ. P. 17(b) & (c) (capacity of representative parties).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85K.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a parent has an independent cause of action to recover medical expenses and other pecuniary losses incurred on behalf of an injured minor child as a result of a defendant’s negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85K (preserving negligence claims against certain charitable organizations subject to limitations); G.L. c. 233, § 20B (recognizing parent‑child relationship in context of medical testimony); see also Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153, 167–68 (1973) (recognizing independent claims related to injuries within the family context, by analogy).

G.L. c. 233, \u00a7 20B.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a parent has an independent cause of action to recover medical expenses and other pecuniary losses incurred on behalf of an injured minor child as a result of a defendant’s negligence. See G.L. c. 231, § 85K (preserving negligence claims against certain charitable organizations subject to limitations); G.L. c. 233, § 20B (recognizing parent‑child relationship in context of medical testimony); see also Diaz v. Eli Lilly & Co., 364 Mass. 153, 167–68 (1973) (recognizing independent claims related to injuries within the family context, by analogy).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: This action is brought under the common law of negligence of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, as informed and supplemented by: a. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence; not applicable here because J.M. is eight years old and not contributorily negligent, but confirming the general framework);

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85K and 85L.proposition: This action is brought under the common law of negligence of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, as informed and supplemented by: c. G.L. c. 231, §§ 85K and 85L (addressing negligence actions and, where applicable, claims against charitable organizations and associated standards of care and liability limitations);

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: This action is brought under the common law of negligence of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, as informed and supplemented by: d. G.L. c. 260, § 2A (three‑year statute of limitations for personal injury actions, which this action meets, as it is filed within three years of the September 15, 2023 incident).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover interest on any judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B (pre‑judgment interest in personal injury actions) and G.L. c. 235, § 8 (post‑judgment interest).

G.L. c. 235, \u00a7 8.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover interest on any judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B (pre‑judgment interest in personal injury actions) and G.L. c. 235, § 8 (post‑judgment interest).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts rules.
